title: How to Prepare Your Body for Outdoor Activities With AS

content: You’re having a good day. Your ankylosing spondylitis symptoms are behaving, and you're feeling great. Naturally, you decide today is the perfect time to take the kids to Six Flags Darien Lake. Fast forward to the next morning:  Your body feels like you’ve ridden the roller coaster 100 times. Ouch.

But here’s the thing: You can have fun outdoors without paying for it later. All you need to do is do a little planning. I’ve outlined some simple steps to help you prepare your body before you take on your next outdoor family outing.
Stretch
We’re not talking about Cirque du Soleil-level moves here. Before you head out, a few gentle stretches can do wonders for your joints and muscles.

Aim for back, hips, and hamstring stretches as those areas love to stiffen up with AS. Hold each stretch for 15 to 30 seconds. Don’t bounce as you stretch. Slow and steady wins the day. Think sloth, stretch like a sloth, and your body will thank you tomorrow.

sections.heading: Hydrate
content: I know, I know, drinking water is the answer to everything, right? But seriously, staying hydrated helps keep your joints lubricated and can make a huge difference in how your body feels after a day of activity. Aim to drink at least eight glasses throughout the day before your adventure.
Pace yourself

I get it, you’re excited. But trying to conquer an entire amusement park in one go is a recipe for disaster. Break up the day with plenty of breaks. Find a shady spot, sit down, and watch your kids have fun. Let your body recharge. If anyone asks why you’re resting so much, tell them you’re “taking it all in.”
Wear supportive shoes

As tempting as it is to wear those adorable sandals, your feet will hate you later. Invest in some solid, supportive shoes with good arch support. Your feet are the foundation for your body, and when they’re happy, the rest of you will be too. Trust me. Cute shoes at the park are not worth the pain.

sections.heading: Dress for success
content: Wear loose-fitting, breathable clothing so you can move freely. Layers are your best friend because they let you adjust to the weather, whether it’s blazing hot or chilly in the shade. Don’t forget sun protection. A comfy hat and some sunscreen will help you avoid the added discomfort of sunburn.
Warm up before the big day

The day before your outing, get moving with some gentle exercise. A short walk or some light yoga will get your body in the groove without overdoing it. This little warm-up session helps get your joints ready for what’s to come. Prime the engine. Start slow so you don’t stall later.
Use assistive tools

If your body needs a little extra help, don’t hesitate to use a cane, a walking stick, or even a back brace. There’s no shame in making things easier for yourself, especially if it means you can enjoy more of the day with less pain. Additionally, these tools can provide extra support during those long walks or standing in line for rides with your kids.

sections.heading: Snack smart
content: Eating the right snacks can help keep your energy up and inflammation down. Avoid the temptation of sugary, greasy foods (I know, funnel cake is calling your name). Reach for anti-inflammatory snacks like nuts or berries. They’ll give you the fuel you need to power through the day without causing your AS to throw a tantrum.
Take pain management seriously

Have a pain management plan ready even if you feel good. Use methods like a heating pad, gentle stretching, and medication as prescribed. Don't wait for pain. Be proactive. If you need a little extra help, bring along some over-the-counter pain relief, just in case. No one will judge you for planning. You’ll be the superhero who avoided a next-day flare.

Listen, staying active with ankylosing spondylitis is no small feat, and the fact that you're getting out there and making memories with your family is amazing. Even if you wake up feeling a bit sore the next morning, you did something great. You're showing your kids — and yourself — that AS doesn't control your life.
